definitions.definition: a method, style or manner of doing something
definitions.sensetop: way to do somethingway of doing somethingway (that)…in the… wayin the way (that)…in a way that…

examples.text: I prefer to do things the easy way.
I love him and I think he feels **the same way**.

a sure-fire way to get him to do whatever I want

They have never contributed in any meaningful way to our civilization.
We did it the old-fashioned way.
We expect computers to react a certain way, in certain situations.

The only way to avoid GM ingredients is to buy certified organic food.
University changed the way I viewed the world.
I don't agree with his way of thinking.

definitions.definition: a particular manner or style of behaviour

examples.text: They grinned at her in a friendly way.
**It was not his way** to admit that he had made a mistake.
Don't worry, if she seems quiet—**it's just her way**.

She worked hard to act in an honest way.
‘Hi there,’ said Tom in a friendly way.
She's behaving in a very mysterious way.

I could tell he liked her from the way he looked at her.

definitions.definition: the typical way of behaving and living of a particular group of people

examples.text: After ten years I'm used to the strange British ways.
She always said that the old ways were the best.

definitions.definition: a route or road that you take in order to reach a place

examples.text: to **ask somebody the way**
Do you know the way?

the **best/quickest/shortest way** from A to B

Is this the right way to the station?
The quickest way to the house is through the woods.
We parted ways once we went off to college.

definitions.definition: the route along which somebody/something is moving; the route that somebody/something would take if there was nothing stopping them/it

examples.text: **Get out of my way!** I'm in a hurry.

definitions.definition: a road, path or street for travelling along

examples.text: There's a way across the fields.

definitions.definition: used in the names of streets

examples.text: 106 Headley Way

definitions.definition: a particular direction; in a particular direction

examples.text: Which way did they go?

Kids were running **this way and that** *(= in all directions)*.

Try it the other way around.
Which way up does this box go?

definitions.definition: a means of going into or leaving a place, such as a door or gate

examples.text: the **way in/out**
They escaped out the back way.

definitions.definition: a distance or period of time between two points
definitions.labels: also North American English, informal(figurative)(North American English, informal)

examples.text: A little way up on the left is the Museum of Modern Art.
We had to go **a long way** before we found a place to eat.
September was **a long way off**.

We still have **a ways to go**.

Your birthday is still some way off.

definitions.definition: an area, a part of a country, etc.

examples.text: I think he lives somewhere over Greenwich way.
I'll stop by and see you next time I'm down your way.

definitions.definition: a particular aspect of something

examples.text: I have changed in every way.
It's been quite a day, **one way and another** *(= for several reasons)*.
They're alike in more ways than one.
They're different in every way.
Can I help you in any way?

definitions.definition: a particular condition or state

examples.text: The economy's in a bad way.
I don't know how we're going to manage, **the way things are**.
The way things are going, I think that's achievable.
She is content with the way things are.

definitions.definition: on the other side of the street, etc.

examples.text: Music blared from the open window of the house across the way.

definitions.definition: during the whole journey/period of time

examples.text: She didn't speak a word to me all the way back home.
the whole way to Arizona

I watched the movie the whole way through.

definitions.definition: completely; as much as it takes to achieve what you want

examples.text: I'm fighting him all the way.

definitions.definition: as you make progress with something

examples.text: You'll learn something along the way.

definitions.definition: used to say that things often happen in a particular way, especially when it is not convenient
however you choose to look at a situation
to behave or do things in a particular manner because it is part of your character

examples.text: It's not his fault he's so pompous—he was born that way.

definitions.definition: to be easy compared with what came before

examples.text: It's all downhill from here. We'll soon be finished.

definitions.definition: to become worse or less successful

examples.text: It's been all downhill for his career since then, with four defeats in five games.

definitions.definition: to be easy compared with what came before

examples.text: It's downhill all the way from here. We'll soon be finished.

definitions.definition: to become worse or less successful

examples.text: I started work as a journalist and it was downhill all the way for my health.
It's been all downhill for his career since then, with four defeats in five games.

definitions.definition: to have habits or opinions that you have had for a long time and that you do not want to change

examples.text: Grandma is so set in her ways.

definitions.definition: to have nearly achieved something and be going to achieve it soon

examples.text: She is well on the way to recovery.
He is well on the way to establishing himself among the top ten players in the world.

definitions.definition: by a great amount

examples.text: He was the best by a long way.

definitions.definition: used to introduce a comment or question that is not directly related to what you have been talking about

examples.text: By the way, I found that book you were looking for.
What's the time, by the way?
Oh by the way, if you see Jackie, tell her I'll call her this evening.

definitions.definition: by a route that includes the place mentioned

examples.text: The artist recently arrived in Paris from Bulgaria by way of Vienna.
She came to TV by way of drama school.

definitions.definition: as a form of something; for something; as a means of something

examples.text: He received £600 by way of compensation from the company.
She rolled her eyes by way of an answer and left.

definitions.definition: to start to live or behave in a different way from before

examples.text: He was in trouble with the police as a teenager but now he’s completely changed his ways.
Your father is unlikely to change his ways now.

definitions.definition: to gradually achieve something or move somewhere by being determined and using a lot of effort

examples.text: She clawed her way to the top of her profession.
Slowly, he clawed his way out from under the collapsed building.

definitions.definition: to remove things that are stopping the progress or movement of something

examples.text: The ruling could clear the way for extradition proceedings.

definitions.definition: to happen to you by chance, or when you were not expecting it

examples.text: He took the first job that came his way.
Have any interesting articles come your way recently?

definitions.definition: to have two opposite effects or results
used to say that it does not matter which one of two possibilities happens, is chosen or is true

examples.text: Was it his fault or not? Either way, an explanation is due.
We could meet today or tomorrow—I don't mind one way or the other.

definitions.definition: in all directions

examples.text: Her hair tumbled every which way.

definitions.definition: to move along carefully, for example when it is dark, by touching walls, objects, etc.
to be careful about how you do things, usually because you are in a situation that you are not familiar with

examples.text: She was new in the job, still feeling her way.

definitions.definition: to discover the right route (to a place)

examples.text: I hope you can find your way home.

definitions.definition: to come to a place or a situation by chance or without intending to

examples.text: He eventually found his way into acting.

definitions.definition: to become used to doing something/to lose the habit of doing something

examples.text: The women had got into the way of going up on the deck every evening.

definitions.definition: to prevent somebody from doing something; to prevent something from happening

examples.text: He wouldn't allow emotions to get in the way of him doing his job.

definitions.definition: to get or do what you want, especially when somebody has tried to stop you

examples.text: She always gets her own way in the end.

definitions.definition: to break or fall down

examples.text: The pillars gave way and a section of the roof collapsed.
Her numb leg gave way beneath her and she stumbled clumsily.

definitions.definition: to stop resisting somebody/something; to agree to do something that you do not want to do

examples.text: He refused to give way on any of the points.

definitions.definition: to allow somebody/something to be or go first

examples.text: Give way to traffic already on the roundabout.

definitions.definition: to allow yourself to be very strongly affected by something, especially an emotion

examples.text: Flinging herself on the bed, she gave way to helpless misery.

definitions.definition: to be replaced by something

examples.text: The storm gave way to bright sunshine.
As he drew nearer, his anxiety gave way to relief.

definitions.definition: to have full sexual intercourse with somebody
to have known each other for a long time

examples.text: We go back a long way, he and I.

definitions.definition: to last a long time

examples.text: She seems to make her money go a long way.
A small amount of this paint goes a long way *(= covers a large area)*.
I find that **a little of** Jerry's company can **go a long way** *(= I quickly get tired of being with him)*.

definitions.definition: to help very much/a little in achieving something

examples.text: The new law goes a long way towards solving the problem.

definitions.definition: to make a special effort to do something

examples.text: He would always go out of his way to be friendly towards her.
She went out of her way to help them.

definitions.definition: to do as you choose, especially when somebody has advised you against it

examples.text: It's best to let her go her own way if you don't want a fight.
He's always gone his own way when it comes to design.

definitions.definition: to end a relationship with somebody

examples.text: When the business was sold they went their separate ways.
They decided to go their separate ways after being together for five years.
When we finished school, we all went our separate ways.

definitions.definition: to go in a different direction from somebody you have been travelling with
to travel in the same direction as somebody

examples.text: I'm going your way—I'll walk with you.
I'm going your way, so we can walk together.
She was going my way, so we talked as we walked.

definitions.definition: to go well for you; to be in your favour

examples.text: By the third round he knew the fight was going his way.

definitions.definition: to die
by having an unpleasant experience or by making mistakes

examples.text: She won't listen to my advice so she'll just have to **learn the hard way**.
He learned about the dangers of drugs the hard way.

definitions.definition: to have made a lot of progress

examples.text: We've come a long way since the early days of the project.
The study of genes has come a long way in recent years.

definitions.definition: to be a sensible person
to have or want to have the advantages of two different situations or ways of behaving that are impossible to combine

examples.text: You can't have it both ways. If you can afford to go out all the time, you can afford to pay off some of your debts.

definitions.definition: used to say in an angry way that although you are not happy about something that somebody has said, you are not going to argue

examples.text: Oh OK, then. Have it your own way!

definitions.definition: to have something arranged in the way that you want, even though other people want it to be arranged differently

examples.text: The German team weren't going to let the English have everything their own way.

definitions.definition: to need to make a lot of progress before you can achieve something

examples.text: She still has a long way to go before she's fully fit.

definitions.definition: used to say that something often happens in a particular way, especially when it is out of your control

examples.text: First love affairs have a way of not working out.
Fate has a way of changing the best of plans.

definitions.definition: to be good at dealing with somebody/something

examples.text: He has a way with small children.
She has a way with words *(= is very good at expressing herself)*.

definitions.definition: to persuade somebody to have sex with you
used to explain what you would do if you had total control over something

examples.text: If I had my way, smoking would be banned completely.

definitions.definition: of any type

examples.text: I don't approve of violence in any shape or form.
I can't stand insects in any shape or form.
I do not condone bullying in any way, shape or form.

definitions.definition: on a large/small scale

examples.text: The new delivery service has taken off in a big way.
Many people are investing in a small way in the stock market.
He then started spending money in a big way.

definitions.definition: (to be/become) pregnant
used to show that a statement has more than one meaning

examples.text: With the first goal he used his head in more ways than one.

definitions.definition: used to say what normally happens in a particular situation

examples.text: In the ordinary way, she's not a nervous person.

definitions.definition: how and when you want to, even though this might annoy other people

examples.text: He always does the work, but in his own sweet time.
She just ignores all the criticism and continues in her own sweet way.

definitions.definition: to some extent; not completely

examples.text: In a way it was one of our biggest mistakes.
It's more interesting, in some ways, to watch what's going on behind the scenes here.
In a certain way, all of that is true.

definitions.definition: in a manner that is appropriate to or typical of a person or thing but that may seem unusual to other people

examples.text: I expect she does love you in her own way.
The building is very attractive in its own way.
He was attractive in his own way.

definitions.definition: stopping somebody from moving or doing something

examples.text: You'll have to move—you're in my way.
I left them alone, as I felt I was in the way.
There were several rocks in the way.

definitions.definition: used in questions and negative sentences to talk about the types of something that are available

examples.text: There isn't much in the way of entertainment in this place.

definitions.definition: to avoid somebody

examples.text: Let's keep out of her way while she's in such a bad mood.

definitions.definition: to be familiar with a place, subject, etc.
to make a lot of money easily and feel very pleased about it
to get yourself into or out of a situation by lying
to deliberately avoid seeing somebody/something

examples.text: Prison officers know what's going on, but look the other way.

definitions.definition: to become lost

examples.text: We lost our way in the dark.
She lost her way in the fog.

definitions.definition: to forget or move away from the purpose or reason for something

examples.text: I feel that the project has lost its way.
This project seems to have lost its way.

definitions.definition: to allow somebody/something to pass; to allow somebody/something to take the place of somebody/something

examples.text: Make way for the Lord Mayor!

definitions.definition: to move or get somewhere; to make progress

examples.text: Will you be able to **make your own way** to the airport *(= get there without help, a ride, etc.)*?
Is this your plan for **making your way in the world**?

definitions.definition: to stop behaving badly
(to take/find) an acceptable course of action that avoids two extreme positions
used to show that you are certain about something

examples.text: It was the wrong decision—there are no two ways about it.

definitions.definition: used to say that there is no possibility that you will do something or that something will happen

examples.text: ‘Do you want to help?’ ‘No way!’
No way am I going to drive them there.
There's no way we could afford that sort of money.

definitions.definition: during the journey

examples.text: He stopped for breakfast on the way.
She grabbed her camera and bag on her way out.
We didn't stop on the way north.
They bought some supplies on the way.
We stopped for a drink on the way home.
On the way back, he invited me to his home for drinks.

definitions.definition: going or coming

examples.text: I'd better be on my way *(= I must leave)* soon.
The letter should be on its way to you.
Then he went off on his merry way.

definitions.definition: not yet born

examples.text: They've got three kids and one on the way.

definitions.definition: to make it possible for somebody to do something or for something to happen

examples.text: The agreement could open the way for the country to pay off its debts.

definitions.definition: in the opposite position, direction or order

examples.text: I think it should go on the other way round.

definitions.definition: the opposite situation

examples.text: I didn't leave you. It was the other way round *(= you left me)*.

definitions.definition: in a safe place where somebody/something cannot be hurt or injured or do any damage to somebody/something

examples.text: She put the knife in a drawer, out of harm’s way.
I prefer the children to play in the garden where they’re out of harm’s way.

definitions.definition: no longer stopping somebody from moving or doing something

examples.text: I moved my legs out of the way so that she could get past.
I didn't say anything until Dad was out of the way.

definitions.definition: finished; dealt with

examples.text: Our region is poised for growth once the election is out of the way.

definitions.definition: used in negative sentences to mean ‘unusual’

examples.text: She had obviously noticed nothing out of the way.

definitions.definition: not on the route that you planned to take

examples.text: I'd love a ride home—if it's not out of your way.
The supermarket is a bit out of my way.
The library is slightly out of my way.

definitions.definition: a point at which two people or groups of people decide to separate

examples.text: These events led to a final parting of the ways.

definitions.definition: to create a situation in which somebody will be able to do something or something can happen

examples.text: This decision paved the way for changes in employment rights for women.

definitions.definition: to make enough money to pay what it costs to keep it going

examples.text: The bridge is still not paying its way.

definitions.definition: to pay for everything yourself without having to rely on anyone else’s money
to walk carefully, choosing the safest, driest, etc. place to put your feet

examples.text: She picked her way delicately over the rough ground.
We picked our way carefully over the jagged rocks.

definitions.definition: to make somebody annoyed or angry, often without intending to, by doing or saying something that offends them

examples.text: She tends to rub people up the wrong way.

definitions.definition: to realize or admit that you have done something wrong and decide to change your behaviour

examples.text: Will they realize the error of their ways before it is too late?

definitions.definition: to find that it is possible or convenient to do something

examples.text: Small builders cannot see their way clear to take on many trainees.

definitions.definition: to get an idea of what is likely to happen before deciding what to do
to do something first so that other people can follow
to make it easier for somebody/something to develop or make progress

examples.text: These negotiations are intended to smooth the path to a peace treaty.
We’re trying to smooth the way for women who want to resume their careers.

definitions.definition: to (not) prevent somebody from doing something

examples.text: If you believe you can make her happy, I won't stand in your way.
He wanted to go to college and would let nothing stand in his way.

definitions.definition: to be bisexual (= sexually attracted to both men and women)
to end a difficult situation by choosing the simplest solution even if it is not the best one

examples.text: He took the easy way out and didn’t go to the meeting.
She took the easy way out and paid someone to write the article for her.

definitions.definition: to be offended by a remark that was not intended to be offensive

examples.text: Don't take this the wrong way, but maybe you're trying a bit too hard.

definitions.definition: to make excuses and give reasons for not doing something; to manage to get yourself out of a difficult situation

examples.text: I managed to talk my way out of having to give a speech.

definitions.definition: that is the situation and we cannot change it, so we must accept it
there are many different ways to achieve something
in my opinion
having started

examples.text: Preparations are well under way for a week of special events in May.

definitions.definition: a plan of action that is likely to be successful

examples.text: Personal electronic health records are the way forward for effective healthcare in the future.

definitions.definition: something that allows you to join a group of people, an industry, etc. that it is difficult to join, or to understand something that it is difficult to understand
the typical pattern of behaviour of a person or group

examples.text: the American way of life
She loved the Spanish way of life and immediately felt at home there.
the beliefs and practices of the Hindu way of life

definitions.definition: the way that most people behave; the way that things happen, which you cannot change

examples.text: The rich and powerful make the decisions—that's the way of the world.

definitions.definition: used to say that somebody else has either to agree with your opinion or to leave
the methods and materials available for doing something

examples.text: ways and means of raising money
Newspapers have ways and means of getting hold of secret information.

definitions.definition: used to tell somebody that you are pleased about something they have done

examples.text: Good work, guys! Way to go!
Way to go! I wish I could do that!

definitions.definition: the way to make somebody like or love you

examples.text: The way to a man's heart is through his stomach *(= by giving him good food)*.

definitions.definition: if you really want to do something then you will find a way of doing it
a series of victories or successes

examples.text: He'll look to continue his winning ways with a victory in Mexico on 16 February.

definitions.definition: to do something from beginning to end, especially when it takes a lot of time or effort

examples.text: She worked her way through the pile of documents.

definitions.definition: to have a job or series of jobs while studying, travelling, etc. in order to pay for your education, etc.
to move regularly to a more senior position in a company

examples.text: He worked his way up from messenger boy to account executive.

wordOrigin: Old English weg, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch weg and German Weg, from a base meaning ‘move, carry’.
